1.q_string: A body of mass \(m\) is accelerated uniformly from rest to a speed \(v\) in a time \(T\). The instantaneous power delivered to the body as a function of time, is given by:
The power of a pump, which can pump \(200 \mathrm{~kg}\) of water to a height of \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) in \(10 \mathrm{~s}\), will be \(\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

The relationship between the force ' \(F\) ' and the position ' \(x\) ' of a body is as shown in the figure. What will be the work done in displacing the body from \(x=1 \mathrm{~m}\) to \(\mathrm{x}=5 \mathrm{~m}\) ?
A stone of mass \(500 \mathrm{~g}\) is thrown vertically upwards with a velocity of \(15 m s^{-1}\). Calculate the potential energy at the greatest height.
If under the action of a force \((4 i+j+3 k) N\), a particle moves from position \(r_{1}=3 i+2 j-6 k\) to positions \(r_{2}=14 i+13 j+9 k\), then the work done will be:

\(300 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done in sliding a \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) block, up an inclined plane to a height of 10 meters. Taking value of acceleration due to gravity ' \(g\) ' to be \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\), work done against friction is:
The potential energy of a body is given by \(A-B x^{2}\). The magnitude of force acting on the particle is:

A force of \(60 N\) acts on a body which moves it through a distance of \(4 m\) on a horizontal surface. What is the work done, if the direction of the force is at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal surface?

An electric pump is used to fill an overhead tank of capacity \(9 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) kept at a height of \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) above the ground. If the pump takes 5 minutes to fill the tank by consuming \(10 \mathrm{~kW}\) power, then the efficiency of the pump must be (take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) )
A cricket ball is hit for a six leaving the bat at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal with kinetic energy \(K\). At the top, Kinetic energy of the ball is:
A body of mass \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving in a vertical circular path of radius \(1 \mathrm{~m}\). The difference between the kinetic energies at its highest and lowest positions is:

A mass \(m\) is attached to the end of a rod of length \(I\). The mass goes around a vertical circular path with the other end hinged at the centre. What should be the minimum velocity of mass at the bottom of the circle, so that the mass completes the circle?

An isolated particle of mass \(m\) is moving in a horizontal plane \((x-y)\), along the \(x\)-axis, at a certain height above the ground. It suddenly explodes into two fragments of masses \(\mathrm{m} / 4\) and \(3 \mathrm{~m} / 4\). An instant later, the smaller fragment is at \(y=+15 \mathrm{~cm}\). The larger fragment at this instant is at:

A bullet of mass \(10 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg}\) moving with a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) hits an ice block \(\left(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\) of \(990 \mathrm{~g}\) kept at rest on a frictionless floor and gets embedded in it. If ice takes \(50 \%\) of KE lost by the system, the amount of ice melted (in grams) approximately is: \((\mathrm{J}=4.2 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{cal})\) (Latent heat of ice \(=80 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{g}\) )

A particle is placed at the origin and a force \(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{Kx}\) is acting on it (where \(\mathrm{K}\) is positive constant). If \(U(0)=0\), the graph of \(U(x)\) versus \(x\) will be (where \(u\) is potential energy function)
A body of mass \(m\), accelerates uniformly from rest to \(V_{1}\) in time \(t_{1}\). The instantaneous power after time \(t\) is:

The potential energy of a conservative system is given by \(U=a y^{2}-b y\), where \(y\) represents the position of the particle, both a and \(b\) are constants. What is the force acting on the system?
If at the highest point of parabolic path kinetic energy is equal to potential energy, the angle of projection would be:
Calculate the kinetic energy of a body of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) moving with a velocity \(2 m s^{-1}\).
A truck and a car moving with same kinetic energy are stopped by equal retarding force. Which of them will be stopped in shorter distance?
A ball tied to a string is swung in a vertical circle. Which of the following remains constant?
If \(\mathrm{F}\) is a force and \(\mathrm{d}\) is the displacement in the direction of force then the work done by the force is given by:

q_option: Force and displacement are at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\)
Eorce and displacement are in the same direction
Force and displacement are perpendicular to each other
Force and displacement are at an angle of \(75^{\circ}\)
1.q_string: In which case is the work done zero?
